abstracts.cdata!:
The Railway Restructuring Project for
            Poland had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Following are some of the lessons learned: Under the
            Project, a total of 37,000 employees, or over 20 percent of
            Polish State Railways (PKP) labor force was reduced between
            August 2000 and January 2003 rapidly but smoothly with no
            evidence of labor tension. Implementation of the overall
            Program, in particular the legal and organizational
            restructuring to split a monolithic Railways into a number
            of subsidiaries and the parent company, was highly
            satisfactory. A protracted period of project preparation
            time can be worthwhile when: (1) it enables the negotiations
            necessary to build political will for a difficult social
            change, (2) it keeps dialogue open while events bring more
            clarity and pressure on the decision makers. Even
            substantial restructuring successes can fail to achieve
            financial goals when the overall business environment
            evolves negatively. Neither PKP nor Agency for Retraining
            and Reemployment ( KAAZ) really saw World Bank social
            safeguards as part of their core activity and to undertake
            the post-layoff social monitoring. The European Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development loan did not include a social
            monitoring component and started one year ahead of the Bank
            loan. An explicit project performance indicator should have
            been included related to the monitoring and evaluation of
            the labor redundancy activities.
